Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Lord Uther! Lord Uther!

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: It's done. A truce. We meet at the river.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: Talk. Lovers murmuring to each other...

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: I should butcher all and every one of them. Merlin, what is this wagging of tongues?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Just show the sword.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Speak the words.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: One land, one king! That is my peace!

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: Me, yield!?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: He has given. Now you must.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: The land from here to the sea is yours if you will enforce the King's will.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: I must have her.

Speaker: lot
Dialogue: What? You're mad! What about the alliance?

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: I must have her.

Speaker: lot
Dialogue: And risk all you've won? This castle commands the sea gate to the kingdom.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: You will be mine. Wife and queen, bed and crown.

Speaker: igrayne
Dialogue: I want no other crown and no other bed than those I have.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: Merlin! Where are you!?

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: Have you found him?

Speaker: ulfius
Dialogue: No--

Speaker: hag
Dialogue: What a hurry you were in this morning, good sir. You forgot to give this old woman a coin.

Speaker: ulfius
Dialogue: I saw you half a day's gallop from here. I asked you if you had seen Merlin. I returned here straight away. How did -

Speaker: hag
Dialogue: --I heard. I have come. I am also Merlin.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: I have walked my way since the beginning of time. Sometimes I give, sometimes I take. It is mine to know which, and when.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: Dumb riddles, Merlin. I am your King.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: I know the storm inside you, and what it has wrought. The alliance I forged is wrecked.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: For Igrayne. One night with her. Do it. Use the magic.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: You will swear by your true kingship to grant me what I wish. Then you shall have it.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: I swear it. By Excalibur and the holy--

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: --What issues from your lust will be mine. Swear it again.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: I swear it.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Come.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: I hold the balance of all things in my summoning. Arise mists. Come fog.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Mount your horse.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Ride straight to the castle, across the sea of fog.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: But the cliff, the sea...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Ride across! Across the bridges of desire. Your lust will hold you up. For I have just woven it into the fabric of the world. This is magic - making solid what is in the mind, and unsolid, that which is already solid.

Speaker: rider
Dialogue: Wake up in there. It is I.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Papa... Papa...

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: My father is dead...

Speaker: igrayne
Dialogue: Look, here is your father. It was just a dream, little one.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: It is done. The future has found root in the present.

Speaker: igrayne
Dialogue: When did it happen? Where?

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: In the camp of Uther, my lady, just after nightfall.

Speaker: igrayne
Dialogue: It can't be. He came to me, to his bed, last night.

Speaker: lady
Dialogue: It was his spirit, yearning for you in his hour of death, that visited you.

Speaker: igrayne
Dialogue: His spirit?

Speaker: igrayne
Dialogue: Tintagel Castle falls to Uther. But what shall become of me, and the child I bear?

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: I want her, Merlin. I cannot be without her. Tintagel is mine. Can I take her now? Tell me!

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: Three horses died under me, so hard did I spur them here. Is it born? Is it alive?

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: Out!

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: What is it, lady?

Speaker: igrayne
Dialogue: A boy, sir. Rest yourself.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: Send the girl away.

Speaker: igrayne
Dialogue: She is just a child -

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: Out!

Speaker: igrayne
Dialogue: Go now. Come back later.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: She watches me with her father's eyes.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: Igrayne, is he mine, or -

Speaker: igrayne
Dialogue: The night he died, a man loved me with great fierceness. He looked like my husband, spoke like, smelled like, felt like my own husband. But it was not he, for he was already dead. It wasn't his spirit, for this child, who was conceived that night, is flesh and blood. I know nothing more.

Speaker: igrayne
Dialogue: No--

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: Through him, I will learn to love them, for I am tired of battle. I will stay by his side and  his mother's...

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: Here. It's hungry.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: Merlin! Out of the sick sleep at last.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Doing what I did for you, it wasn't easy, you know. It takes it's toll. It took nine moons to get back my strength.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Now you must pay me.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: I?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: The child is mine, Uther. I have come for him.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: The oath. You didn't say--

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: You didn't ask!

Speaker: igrayne
Dialogue: Uther, is it true? Don't let him take the child.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: I swore an oath, Igrayne. I made a pact with Merlin.

Speaker: igrayne
Dialogue: It was you? You came to me that night. You are the father.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: It's not for you, Uther, hearth and home, wife and child.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: To kill and be king, is that all?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Maybe not even that, Uther. I thought once that you were the one to unite the land under one sword. But it'll take another, a greater king...

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: You strike me with words as hard as steel.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: They are not weapons, my friend, but truths. You betrayed the Duke, stole his wife and took his castle, now no one trusts you. Lot, Uryens, your allies will turn against you. Give me the child, Uther, I will protect him. Go back to your war tent.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: By the oath, take the devil child. Take him!

Speaker: igrayne
Dialogue: WHY?... Why must he have the baby?

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Merlin, are you now the father, and the mother, of the baby?

Speaker: uryens
Dialogue: The King's sword. I must have it.

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: Merlin, where are you? To weave a mist, to hide us...

Speaker: uther
Dialogue: No one shall have the sword. No one shall wield Excalibur but me.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Into the spine of the dragon!  Uther... I loved you, mighty child.

Speaker: lot
Dialogue: Let me.

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: It is a dark hour... everywhere lawlessness and destruction, and no one to lead us out of it.

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: Listen all. I am Sir Ector of Morven and these are my sons. You would wrong me, for I have never stolen from others, or destroyed the fruit of the land.

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: The people's anger is just. It is sad that for our own safety, we will have to ride to the tournament with these robber knights.

Speaker: bishop
Dialogue: This is Easter day, when Christ rose again. Who will find strength in victory of arms? Who will draw the sword?

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: Arthur, where is Kay's sword? A good squire doesn't forget his knight's sword.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I left it in the tent, sir.

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: Well hurry then, and get it.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It's been stolen....

Speaker: sir kay
Dialogue: Father, I'll go and see what's keeping him.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: If only Kay could have it...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Your sword was stolen, Kay, but here is Excalibur. Is it too late? I hurried--

Speaker: sir kay
Dialogue: Look, Father. Excalibur. Does that mean that I am to be king?

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: Did you free the sword, boy?

Speaker: sir kay
Dialogue: I... did, Father.

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: We must go to the stone at once.

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: Draw it, son!

Speaker: sir kay
Dialogue: Sir, I didn't draw the sword. Arthur gave it to me.

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: Arthur ?!  How did you get the sword, child?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sir... Kay needed a sword. His was stolen. I saw Excalibur, and... I took it.

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: You freed it, son?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I did, Father. I beg your forgiveness.

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: Try the sword, Arthur.

Speaker: uryens
Dialogue: Stand back, Sir Ector, and take your children.

Speaker: lot
Dialogue: We will try again.

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: Let the boy try the sword.

Speaker: bishop
Dialogue: Let the boy try...

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: Go ahead, boy. Don't be afraid.

Speaker: bishop
Dialogue: We have our King, thanks be to God.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Please, Father, rise up. I was your son before I became your King... if I am King.

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: My Lord, you are King, all the more because you are not my son, and I am not your father.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Who is, then?

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: I don't know. Merlin brought you to me when you were newly born and charged me to raise you as my own. At first, I did so because I feared Merlin, later because I loved you.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Who is Merlin?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Speak of the devil!...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: I am Merlin. Counselor to kings. Wizard and beggar. Prophet and...  I have feasted on thunderbolts, I savored my death before I got myself born. I--

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Whose son am I?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: You are the son of King Uther, and the fair Igrayne... you are King Arthur.

Speaker: lot
Dialogue: Merlin, we haven't forgotten you. This is more of your trickery.

Speaker: uryens
Dialogue: You're trying to foist a boy of dubious birth upon us. You want to shame us?

Speaker: lot
Dialogue: Lord Leondegrance, join us against the boy. Surely you can see he is only Merlin's tool.

Speaker: leondegrance
Dialogue: No. I, Leondegrance, Lord of Camelyarde, saw the drawing of Uther's sword, and witnessed no trickery. If a boy has been chosen, a boy shall be king.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: ...Merlin... Merlin...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Merlin!

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: You called, sir?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You saved me from the arrow...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: But not from your destiny.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I want to thank you.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: That's not why you came.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Merlin, help me. I need your help. I don't know how--

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: 'Help me, Help me.' Help me get up.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: I'm tired. Doing magic takes its toll, you know. My arms ache terribly...  Once--or is it yet to happen--I stood exposed to the Dragon's breath so that a man could lie one night with a woman. It took me ten moons to recover. I'm sure that story would interest you, since... Well, we'll have to talk about it another time. You're too busy now.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: It is whispered in the forest that...  ...Leondegrance's castle is under siege by Lot and Uryens.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Yes, yes, I know that. Everybody does. Lord Leondegrance is my only ally among the barons and the great knights. I can't lose him.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Well there. You don't need me half as much as you think you do. You already know what must not happen.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I must find the means to save him, then. I was hoping I could ask you for a little magic help, but if it makes you so tired...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It's just that I have no experience, and no men to speak of. How can I--

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Because you must! You and only you. Have you forgotten that it was you who freed Excalibur?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Besides, it will be a good lesson.  The best, if it's not the last.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Maybe you'd like to meet the power that gave you the sword?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: How? Where?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: In the great book.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What book is that?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: The book without pages. Open before you, all around us. You can see it in bits and pieces, for if mortal men were to see it whole and all complete in a single glance, why, it would burn him to cinders.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What?!

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: The dragon! There...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Coiled in the unfathomed depths, it emerges...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: ...It unfolds itself in the storm clouds...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: ...it washes its mane sparkling white in the blackness of seething whirlpools...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: ...its claws are the forks of lightning... its scales glisten in the bark of trees...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: ...its voice is heard in the hurricane...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: ...it is so much more than a scaly monster. It is Everything!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: And if I am to be King of everything, lord and commoner, beast, leaf and rock, I must use its voice, its claws, its power.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: Father, it's the boy King.

Speaker: leondegrance
Dialogue: It is. I will fight my way to his side.

Speaker: uryens
Dialogue: War-wise fighters, grown gray in battle, checkmated by a boy.

Speaker: lot
Dialogue: It's Merlin's trickery, nothing more. I won't swear faith to that wizard's brat.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Let's finish this with a show of force. We have no more tricks and no more advantages.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: No... Arthur--

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You are in my hands, to slay or spare. I need battle lords such as you. Swear faith to me and you shall have mercy.

Speaker: uryens
Dialogue: Noble knights swear faith to a mere squire?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You are right. I'm not yet a knight.  You, Uryens, will knight me.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Then as knight to knight I can offer you mercy.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: What's this, what's this?!

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: I never saw this...

Speaker: uryens
Dialogue: In the name of God, of Saint Michael and Saint George, I give you the right to bear arms, the power to mete justice.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: That duty I will solemnly obey as knight and King.

Speaker: uryens
Dialogue: Rise, my King. I am your humble knight, and I swear allegiance to the courage in your veins, for so strong it is, it's source must be Uther. I doubt you no more.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Owww...

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: It didn't hurt too much, did it?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Ye...

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: --I'm pretty good at stitchery. I've sewn my father's wounds more than once.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: Careful! You'll have to stay still for a few days or you'll tear them open.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: But I have to leave tomorrow. The forests are thick with rebels, invaders plunder our shores...

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: --And damsels in besieged castles are waiting to be rescued?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I didn't know Leondegrance had a daughter.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: Well, then, I shall tell you which knights have maiden daughters, so you can avoid their castles.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: No, I think it's better if you just stay here to heal. At least a week.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I'm going.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: Quiet, or I'll sew up your mouth too.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: Would you rescue me from a fiery dragon, sir?

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: It's just a furry little rabbit that took the bait and sprung the trap.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: You'll find him served up to you tonight, cooked in a most excellent sauce...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: A king must marry, after all.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: ...of course...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I love her. If she would be my queen, my dreams would be answered.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: There are maidens as fair, and fairer than Guenevere. If I put my mind to it, I could see them now, many of them, weeping for love of you, watching the hills for you coming from the high towers of their castles. Offering you their every favor. Rich, clever--but if it is to be Guenevere, so be it.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Who will it be? Put your mind to it, then.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Guenevere. And a beloved friend who will betray you.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Guenevere...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: You're not listening. Your heart is not. Love is deaf as well as blind.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: They are only for you, for in them I mixed things that heal, but not too quickly; and things that make limbs sleepy, preventing escape, but keep one's mind sharp.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What's in them?

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: It is an ancient mixture, containing only soft, unborn grains, and flavored with roses. The rest is secret.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Looking at the cake is like looking at the future. Until you have savored its bitterness and its sweetness, its texture and its perfume, what do you really know? And then, of course, it will he too late.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Too late...

Speaker: sir ector
Dialogue: He is the mightiest and fairest of knights.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: We fought and won battles, and now one man defeats all my knights? I will go.

Speaker: sir kay
Dialogue: A king must not engage in single contest. I'll go again.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Where is Merlin?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I should have left you to fend for yourself.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: I had to weave a little enchantment on the bees so I could get some honey, and I didn't feel up to using any more magic just yet. Anyway, I was in less danger than you'll be in today.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: So you were stealing their honey. They should have killed you.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Come now. So much anger for such a little crime? Are you sure there is nothing else troubling you?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You know full well there is, and I go to meet it now. Come witness my revenge.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Good day to you, sir.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Move aside. This is the King's road, and the knights you joined arms against were his very own.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: I await the King himself. His knights are in need of training.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I am King, and this is Excalibur, sword of kings from the dawn of time. Who are you, and why do you block the way?

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: I am Sir Lancelot of the Lake, from across the sea. I am the best knight in the whole of Christiandom, and I look for the king who is worthy of my sword's service.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: --That is a wild boast. You lack a knight's humility.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Not a boast, sir, but a curse.  Never have I met my match in joust or duel.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Move aside!

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: I will not. You must retreat or prove your kingship in the test of arms, under the eyes of God.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Then may He give me the strength to unhorse you and send you with one blow back across the sea.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Hold! I offer you another lance.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: You joust well, sir. Battle learnt, but tournament fancy. You should ride more forward in the saddle, though.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Yield. I have the advantage.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I will not.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Fight me from your horse or on foot, but fight me. Your avoidance mocks me.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: I sought only not to harm you, sir.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Sir, your rage has unbalanced you. It seems you would fight to the death against a knight who is not your enemy, for a length of road you can ride around.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: So be it, to the death.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: It is you, sir, who knows not the virtue of humility, as a true king must.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What horror is this?  Merlin!

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: The sword is broken. Hope is broken...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: My pride broke it, my rage broke it... Humiliation and defeat lie in ambush even for a king.  This excellent knight who fought with fairness and grace was meant to win. With Excalibur, I tried to change that verdict.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I have lost for all time the ancient sword of my fathers whose power was meant to unite all men, to serve the vanity of a single man.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I am nothing.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Excalibur! Is it true?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: The Lady of the Lake. Take it. Take it, quickly!

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: There are infinite worlds within the infinite coils of the Dragon. In one of them, which I have not traveled, the sword was forged. I only know that the King is returned to us through the instrument of his power. The game continues!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Thanks to God, you are alive.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: I, the best knight in the world, bested! This is a great day, for my search is over. I love you, my King.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You are still the best knight in Christiandom. You gained a hundred advantages over me. It is I who must love you, for through your courage and patience you taught me a bitter lesson.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Then make me your champion and I will always fight in your place.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: But your life and lands are far from here.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: I gave up my castles and my lands!

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: My domain is here, inside this metal skin. And I would pledge to you all that I still own: muscle, bone, blood and the heart that pumps it.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: And a great heart it is. Sir Lancelot, you will be my champion.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: In the name of Jesus Christ and His holy blood, I swear eternal faith to Arthur, King.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: ...We killed every one of them. Burnt their ship...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Lancelot, how did you fare in the North?

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: We spared the lives of a few, so they could sail home and tell their fellows what fate they met at the hands of King Arthur's knights...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: And you, Uryens?

Speaker: uryens
Dialogue: Victory!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Lot, and you?

Speaker: lot
Dialogue: We drove the invaders into the sea.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You, Gawain, the East?

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: The East is ours again.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: The war is over. One land, one King. Peace.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: Let me through. I fought the King's battle too. He must know my story.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Chaos... confusion... brutes... savages... troglodytes... Stand back... make space.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: The moon... the sun... the stars... they spin... they turn... they circle... around us... us...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: You, and you, and you, take up your place. Be wedded to the world. Respect its perfection. All of you, together, be one.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Your ancient wisdom and infinite sight have forged this circle, Merlin. Hereafter we shall come together in a circle, to tell and hear of deeds good and brave. I will build a table where this fellowship shall meet. And a hall around the table. And a castle about the hall.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: And I will marry.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: And the land will have an heir to wield Excalibur.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Knights of the Round Table, good friends, brothers in arms. I send you on a quest harder by far than the battles we have fought together, a quest to uphold always, and everywhere, justice, honor, and truth. Each day shall bring forth a cause, and may each cause bring forth a knight.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: I swear never to rest twice on the same pillow till all men live at peace.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: Good day, sir.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Good day to you.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: I hear the stifled cry for help, I smell the reek of fear...

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: These men repented before God for their evil deeds. Those who would not, met their fate at the end of my sword.  Accept the fruit of my first quest as my wedding gift.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I do. Rise, Lancelot, come with me.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sit beside me, Lancelot.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Your deeds set an example for all other knights. For your gift, ask a gift of me.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Only give me leave to ride out again, to do what I am most able to do, and happiest doing.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: He must stay for the feasting days of our wedding, and tell his deeds himself.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I grant you your wish if you grant Lady Guenevere hers.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: I will stay Madame.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: The knights of Galys approach the camp. It would be politic...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: ...to ride out and meet them.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I will ride with Sir Kay. Lancelot, rest here.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: Don't start a war on my wedding day!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Without Lancelot?!

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: Look Lancelot. The maids and ladies whisper about you. They all dream of winning you, young and old, fair and ugly.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: But surely that's no secret to you, dear Lancelot. You're the bravest and strongest knight they've ever seen, and beauty has kissed your brow.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: The well-kept secret is whether any of them has won your heart.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: I am a fighting man and I am married to the quest. That is enough.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: And there is no maiden in the whole world who inspires you?

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: There is one.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: Who?!

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: You.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: Me?

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Yes. I would swear my love to you.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: To me? But why?

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: I cannot love as a woman the lady who will be wife to my King and my friend. And, in pledging my love to you, I cannot love any other woman.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: I will see you in all women, and I will defend them as I would defend you.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Lord Merlin, are you ill?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: No, no, I need air.

Speaker: uryens
Dialogue: Merlin, don't you join the celebration?

Speaker: uryens
Dialogue: My wife, Merlin. Lady Morgana of Cornwall.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: I remember you, Merlin. I was a child. You took my brother away.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: You left your husband's side? You left your brother's wedding?

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Is that Mandrake, Lord Merlin?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: It is.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Can it truly be used for magic?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Yes... sometimes...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: ...There are many powers in this world.

Speaker: bishop
Dialogue: Drink this the blood of Jesus Christ our Lord.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Sorry. Hungry.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Have I taken too much?

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: I had rabbit yesterday. Today I'll eat fish... No?

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Don't be afraid.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: You're an angel! Not a devil...

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Just a man. A knight in the King's service.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: You're a man?!  ...with metal skin!

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Can I grow metal skin?

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: You've got a lot to learn.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: I'll learn... take me... to the King... What's a... King?

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Very well. Climb up.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: I will run.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Listen, boy, it's more than twenty days from here.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Twenty days!? The world is that big?

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Who will give me my sword?

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: Kitchen knives and greasy spits will be your weapons, boy.

Speaker: fat man
Dialogue: I brew ale, sir--from old shoes--I am an honest tradesman sir. I must sell what I produce. He won't buy ale and he won't pay. Pay up! He leans over the barrel and sucks in the vapors. The vapors are mine.

Speaker: thin man
Dialogue: How would you know I, sir, have the misfortune to live next to this criminal... What loss in that? Not to me! Pay for what? Why?! They are floating on the wind.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Enough!... What is a fair price for the smell of your ale?

Speaker: fat man
Dialogue: That's why we have come to you, sir There's no one else who can tell us.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What does it cost to get drunk on your ale?

Speaker: fat man
Dialogue: At least three shillings, sir.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Give me three shillings.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: For the smell of your ale, the jingle of his coins.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: What did I see today in the wizard's eyes? Censure, because I enjoy a few words with a young handsome knight?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: No, no, of course not. You are young...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: I'm not jealous!

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: It's clear you are, and it irks me.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: No. Yes, I am. I am jealous. I want to write poems about you with moonbeams, make the sea sing your name...

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: A lovestruck page!

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Shh... yes, yes. Sit with me, please... Morgana.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: A steamy, panting, lovestruck page. But what good are songs and poems to me? They are the barter of ordinary love. A gift that reflected your greatness is the only one worthy of your love.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: I showed you all my conjuring tricks...

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: The deepest secrets, the forbidden formulas...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Maybe... maybe...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Merlin, are you counselor to the King, or to my sister?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: At your service, sir.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Then answer me this. For years peace has reigned in the land. Crops grow in abundance, there is no want. Every one of my subjects enjoys his portion of happiness and justice, even those whose tiresome misunderstandings we must resolve here each day. Tell me, Merlin: have we defeated evil, as it seems?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Good and evil; there is never one without the other.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Where hides evil, then, in my kingdom?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Never where you expect it, that's all I know.

Speaker: sir gahalt
Dialogue: If we have peace and justice, why is Lancelot never with us? Why is he always riding out on his quests? He must know where this evil is.

Speaker: sir gawain
Dialogue: Could there be evil within Lancelot himself? To live above human folly, as is his aim, is to be overly proud.

Speaker: sir gahalt
Dialogue: He pays no heed even to the Queens longing for his company.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: What is it you would have your words mean, Sir Gahalt?

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Don't listen to him. You are the Queen.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sir Gahalt, answer the Queen.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: No. I meant not to be angry with you, Sir Gahalt. In the idleness that comes with peace gossip has bread its own evil. You merely repeat it. Please, sir, have one of those apples that Lancelot loves, and in that gesture partake of its goodness.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: Take one, Sir Gahalt.

Speaker: sir gahalt
Dialogue: I am most honored, my lady.

Speaker: sir gawain
Dialogue: Hear me, Lord Arthur, and knights and chieftains: I charge Guenevere with the murder of my brother.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: I didn't... I am innocent.

Speaker: sir gawain
Dialogue: I champion this truth: That Queen Guenevere murdered Sir Gahalt with the aid of sorcery.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: The Queen will be in my charge till a champion steps forward to fight on her behalf.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: Not you, my husband?

Speaker: sir gawain
Dialogue: She must be burnt at the stake. That is the sentence for murder done with magic.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It is. Lords and knights of the Round Table, as her husband I say that this deed was not done by Guenevere. Who among you will champion this truth?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sir Caradoc! You!

Speaker: caradoc
Dialogue: I am torn.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: I will champion you, my lady.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: I thank you, but you are not yet a knight.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: I will find Lancelot! He will come!

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Boys!... boys will be boys...

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: I have found you. The Queen. An apple. Tomorrow. Sir Gawain...

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: --It must wait, child. These good ladies, for whom I intervened once, will honor me with a meal. I am beholden to them now as I was when they begged my protection.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: Why can't you be my champion?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: If I am your judge, I cannot be your champion. When I act as your King, I cannot be your husband.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: And you cannot love me...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: The laws, my laws, must bind everyone, high and low, or they are not laws at all. Lancelot will come...

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: And if he cannot be found, no other knight will champion me, though you beseeched each and every one of them. Why be king if there is no one you can call loyal subject but an eager boy?

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Guenevere, I fight against myself...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Is he coming?

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: He heard Lady Guenevere's request and he said nothing. That is all.

Speaker: sir gawain
Dialogue: My Lord, the sun is upon the field. The Queen has no champion. I demand justice, as is my right.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: So it is.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Let me champion the Queen!

Speaker: sir gawain
Dialogue: Since no knight comes forward, I demand justice--

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Boy, kneel.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: In the name of God, of St. Michael, and St. George, I make you a knight. Rise, Sir...

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: ...Perceval!

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: It's my task to prove the Queen's innocence.

Speaker: sir gawain
Dialogue: The Queen is innocent. I yield to your mercy, Sir Lancelot.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Flesh on flesh. You must press on the wound, Guenevere, hold it, and it will begin to bind.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Merlin, tell me. Now that Guenevere is returned to me...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: What is it my child?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Will I have a son?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Just yes? No mad laughter, no riddles, nothing but a simple yes? That frightens me.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: A king should be afraid, always. The enemy is everywhere. Waiting in ambush in the dark corridors of his castle, on the deer paths of his forest, or in the gray and winding paths of a more tangled forest, in here.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: Flesh on flesh. I will heal you.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: They miss the battlefield. I think we do too.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: But one can still keep a sword sharp riding out in the name of the King's law.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It is not easy for the young ones to learn knightly virtues without the hard teaching of war and quest. It is only your example, Lancelot, that binds them now.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Which is the greatest quality of knighthood? Courage? Compassion? Loyalty? Humility? What do you say, Merlin?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: What?  The greatest? They blend together like the metals we mix to make a good sword.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I didn't ask for poetry. Which is it?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: All right. Truth. It must be truth, above all. When a man lies he murders some part of the world.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Conversation and court life don't suit me. I must take my rest in the forest.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Hasn't Merlin mended your wound?

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: It is deep...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You will be sorely missed. Heal yourself and come back.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Why? You will destroy Arthur, and us...

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: The law forbids it.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: Love demands it.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: There are things about love--

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: --Nothing!

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: By my knight's sword, I swore faith--

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Guenevere...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I am alone and betrayed. By my wife, by my beloved friend, by my knights. And by you. Perhaps most of all by you. For you made me, you forged this wretched life. And like a child tired of a toy, you toss me aside, a babbling lecher trotting after my sister...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: That is my destiny. I have a destiny, too...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: With all your powers, you are content to be ridiculed, laughed at...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: My powers fade, Arthur. I resort to cheap tricks...  Yes! I enjoy every moment of my foolishness, I join in the making of it, so no one can betray me. But you! You betray yourself.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Me? I have lived by the oath of king and knight.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: You betray the boy who drew the sword, the boy who saw the Dragon... the Dragon who moves close by, coiling and uncoiling, restless, looking down, waiting for the King to be a king...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I must do it myself. I must kill them both. Lancelot and Guenevere. Will you ride with me, Merlin?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: I cannot. I must not. Here I must stay.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Crazy old fool. You think yourself a kingmaker. Ha! A meddler, more likely. Look what a mess you've made of things.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: I? Perhaps, perhaps. I'm losing interest, Morgana... I have helped men--or meddled in their affairs, if you would have it that way--since the dawn of time. Now let them live by their own laws. Let them stand on their own feet. The gods of once are gone forever, it is time for men... Morgana, make a man out of me. Kiss me.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: You know what I want. I want the secret of true magic, how to thicken the stuff of dreams and wishes with the flesh of the world.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: That I cannot.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Then I will not.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Why didn't he kill us?

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: He has given up.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: The King without his sword, the land without a king...

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: We are to blame.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: When Arthur built the castle, I carved out a place for myself, where I could laugh or sleep, and no one would bother me.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: People make you laugh?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: They do.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: They don't know how close they live to the edge of delight or disas...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Happiness or horror.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: In the folds of the earth where the forces that hold the world together are more alive, my power is strongest. Here I will possess you, as a man possesses a woman. And the god, the eunuch, the mule that I was, will be no more.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: You are truly magnificent!

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Flattery! Do you think I am ignorant of your stupid little games? Preying on you weakness of others. That's your power, a petty evil. Mine is great. Great plans. Impossible dreams. Laughable endings...

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Merlin, the powers of Summoning, the true Name of the charms of Doing and Undoing. Show me!

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: I won't. You would misuse such power. I have paid enough for you, and I will have you.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Make magic, my foolish wizard. For our love. Weave a marvelous room around us, a room worthy of our coupling.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: What do you want? You must desire it for me to weave it.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Walls of shining crystals, burning with red fire, furnishings of metals and jewels never seen by man...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Desire it and it will be as you desire.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: It's only a semblance. You disappoint me.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Don't touch the walls. Come close to me.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Do it, Merlin, the deepest secret. Fix it with the charm of Making, for our endless pleasure.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: For you...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Has no one seen Merlin?

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: Did you see? The King was without Excalibur...

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: I'll weep for you, brother, for a King must not weep.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Do you know what Guenevere's maids have whispered?

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: That when the King returned from battle...

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: ...Guenevere would unlace his armor and massage the burns where metal rubbed on flesh...

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: ...She would prepare a bath for you, mixing special ointment in the water...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Guenevere! You are--

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: The moon flows in my blood to meet your seed. And already I bear him who will be King.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: I could easily kill you, brother. But I want you to live to see our son be King. In me, the blood of Cornwall will have its revenge; in me, the blood of Uther will show its dark side.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Stand back, all of you. Through my own body I have nurtured him with my potions. I made him. I alone can give him life.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Who will ride the labyrinths of the forest, to the very root of his soul, to the very ends of the earth, to find the secret that will redeem us from the evil that has fallen upon us, and make this chalice, and ourselves, whole again?

Speaker: sir gawain
Dialogue: I will ride forth in the name of that quest, and commit my strength and my soul to it.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: I will go.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Gawain, a dreadful fear is upon me, that we may never meet again, that the fellowship will be no more...

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: We will find the secret or die.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Kay, I know your heart yearns to go, but I am prisoner to my duties, and you must be to yours, at my side.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: The blood of this knight will feed the god in the earth, he is weak with hunger, and he will be made strong by this blood. Then he will plant his seed, and the land will be fertile once again.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Arthur, forgive me. I die without the secret. I have failed.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Look, Mordred, a true prize for the giant. The lamb rides into our jaws.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: You must kill him, for this knight is dear to your father. You must do it and learn to enjoy your father's pain.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Have you found what you search for? Have you found what Arthur seeks?

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: You haven't, or you would be smiling now in the face of death. Your quest is an impossible one.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: That it might be impossible makes it all the more necessary.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Fool!  Do it, Mordred!

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Feel the life through the dagger, child. It belongs to you.

Speaker: mordred
Dialogue: I feel it, Mother. I will give his blood to the giant.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: You didn't kill him! You didn't kill him!

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: My dear, sweet boy...

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: We'll become good friends.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Where are you going, Lancelot, in your iron tomb? Still trying to save the world?  The best... the bravest... the greatest... fool that ever lived. Now the world rots. Death is king of the earth. And it is you who make it so, Lancelot.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: What is the secret of the chalice? Who does it serve?

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: The chalice. The secret was in my grasp. I let it slip, afraid for myself. A question was asked. I didn't understand. I didn't try. I failed...

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: Your son Mordred is at the gate.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: At last...

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: Don't recognize him. You were trapped by Morgana's sorcery.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: ...Mordred is real, alive, my own flesh and blood. I will see him, I must.

Speaker: mordred
Dialogue: Father...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Rise, Mordred.

Speaker: mordred
Dialogue: I have come to claim what is mine, Father.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I recognize you only as my son, no more.

Speaker: mordred
Dialogue: And you are the great King? The lords have rebelled. Invaders attack the coasts. Crops don't grow. There is nothing but plague and hunger in the land. Only I am feared. I will be king. You may have lost Excalibur, but I have found my own weapon of power. There.

Speaker: mordred
Dialogue: The very spear that pierced the side of Christ as he died on the cross.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Your mother told you that?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I cannot offer you the land, only my love...

Speaker: mordred
Dialogue: And I offer only this, Father. To commit with passion and pleasure all the evils that you failed to commit, as man and king.

Speaker: mordred
Dialogue: We will embrace only in battle. Father, and I will touch you only with the blade of my spear.

Speaker: mordred
Dialogue: I will muster a great force of knights, and I will return to fight for what is mine.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: So be it.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Illusions. I will never find it again... I am sorry, woman, that I frightened you.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Good woman, do you have any food? Some water?...

Speaker: peasant
Dialogue: The little we had, we gave to Mordred's knights. He has taken this land. Tell the King that now we must look to Mordred.

Speaker: second peasant
Dialogue: But we will give you some water...

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: I have lost my horse, my armor, my sword. I have lost my way. I have lost my strength. I have lost everything... I will not lose hope.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: Who does it serve?

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: You, my lord.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: I have waited long for you. Once you almost saw, but fear blinded you. Why am I served from the chalice?

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Because you and the land are one.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: I am wasting away and I cannot die. And I cannot live.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: You and the land are one. Drink from the chalice. You will be reborn and the land with you.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: But who am I?

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: You are my lord and King. You are Arthur.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I didn't know how empty was my soul until it was filled.

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: Perceval, you have returned!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Ready my knights for battle; they will ride with their King once more. I have lived through others far too long! Lancelot carried my honor and Guenevere my guilt. My knights have fought my causes. Mordred carries my sins. Now, at last, I will rule.

Speaker: nun
Dialogue: Go away. No man is allowed beyond these doors.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I am Arthur.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Guenevere, accept my forgiveness, and put your heart to rest. We have suffered to long. I have always loved you, and I still love you.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: I loved you much, as King, and sometimes as husband, but one cannot gaze too long at the sun in the sky.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Forgive me, my wife, if you can. I was not born to live a man's life, but to be the stuff of future memory. The fellowship was a brief beginning, a fair time that cannot be forgotten; and because it will not be forgotten, that fair time may come again. Now once more I must ride with my knights to defend what was, and the dream of what could be.

Speaker: guenevere
Dialogue: I have kept it.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I never dared to hope all these years that it was in your keeping.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I have often thought that in the hereafter of our lives, when I owe no more to the future and can be just a man, that we may meet, and you will come to me and claim me as yours, and know that I am your husband. It is a dream I have...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Guenevere...

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: It is only me and my son. All other knights of the dukedom have rallied to Mordred.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What horror is that?

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: Mordred, sir. He digs for precious metals, with which he buys the loyalty of men at arms, binding them to his side.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I am outnumbered ten to one by Mordred's forces. Merlin, I need you at my side as you were once, my friend, to give me courage. There are no war tricks that will fool Mordred. He was weaned on blood.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: More than I ever did, I need you now. Where are you, Merlin? Is it true that Morgana has trapped you?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: ...If only you could be at my side, Merlin, to see me wield Excalibur once more...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What is this place? It is rumored Merlin, that you drew your power from these circles...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Quiet. You'll wake the men, and they must fight tomorrow for their very lives.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: I know. I have heard noises and echoes through the stones...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What is this place, Merlin?

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: It is like a tree. The roots of the stones spread out across the land and they draw on the thoughts and actions of men. Like sap those human matters course through the stones feeding the stars that are the leaves of the tree. And the stars whisper back to men the future course of events.  But the earth is being torn apart, its metals stolen, and the balance is broken and the lines of power no longer converge. In fact, I nearly didn't make it in one piece.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: But, I'm here.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Where have you been these many years? Is it true that Morgana--

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: --Stories... You brought me back. Your love brought me back. Back to where you are now, in the land of dreams...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Is this a dream? Tell me, Merlin!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Merlin?!

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: Merlin, will I live...?  ...I was dreaming...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Of Merlin?

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: Yes. He spoke to me. He said I would fight bravely tomorrow. I have never dreamed of Merlin before.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I dreamed of him too... Merlin lives! He lives in our dreams now, in that dark and shadowy place that is as strong and real as this more solid one. He speaks to us from there.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: I have returned, enchantress. You are beautiful, magnificent. Have you used up all the magic you stole from me to keep yourself young? Have you any magic left to do battle with Merlin?

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: You provoke me, Merlin.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: What's behind that beauty? A wizened, cold-hearted snake.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: You are a snake about to strike!

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: And I am the staff that drives the snake back.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: Burning with the fire of desire, I am the flames that consume the staff to ashes.

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: I am the cloudburst that quenches the flames.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: I am the desert, where water disappears--

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: --I am the sea, which covers the desert forever under its weight.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: --I am the fog and mists that rise up from the sea, escaping...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: Fog and mist! You couldn't be that. You don't have enough magic.

Speaker: morgana
Dialogue: ...I have the desire and I have the magic...

Speaker: merlin
Dialogue: You are mine at last. I am the sea and you will never escape me. Fog and Mist...!?

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: A fog is rising, sir.

Speaker: mordred
Dialogue: That cannot be.

Speaker: mordred
Dialogue: My mother has a sense for such things. She said there would be no fog.

Speaker: mordred
Dialogue: ...Mother?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Kay, you will lead the attack. Perceval, you will stay with me.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Be cautious, my brother.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: In this battle there is one thing I must do, that no one else can. Find Mordred and kill him.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: There are too many on Mordred's side. We cannot hold out much longer.

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: He can be no other.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Lancelot?... It is Lancelot!

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: No, my lord. We seek Mordred.

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: I will join him.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Has anyone seen Lancelot?

Speaker: squire
Dialogue: He lies over there, sir.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Squire! Here!

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Arthur.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Lancelot, I will save you... Don't die.

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: My salvation is to die a Knight of the Round Table.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You are that and much more. You are its greatest knight, you are what is best in men. Now we will be together--

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: --It is the old wound, that has been opened. I have always known it would be the gateway to my death, for it has never healed. Let my heart do its job, my King, and pump me empty...

Speaker: lancelot
Dialogue: Guenevere, has she come to you, is she Queen again?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: She is, Lancelot.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: The fog is lifting. Only we remain alive.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: But for Mordred. Where is Mordred?

Speaker: mordred
Dialogue: Where is Arthur?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: No, Perceval. Now it is time for me to raise my sword.  Mordred, prepare to meet your death.

Speaker: mordred
Dialogue: I wait for you, Father.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Draw the spear from me. Do it.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: There is one thing left to do... Excalibur... And you must do it, Perceval. Leave my wounds, I command you.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: I cannot--

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: --Take Excalibur. Find a pool of calm water and throw the sword into it.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Obey me, Perceval. You must act for me. It is my last order as your King. Do it, and be back!

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: It is too precious a thing. I can't...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: When you threw it in, what did you see?

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: ...I saw nothing.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: My King, I couldn't do it. Excalibur cannot be lost. Other men--

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: --By itself it is only a piece of steel. Its power comes from he who wields it. For now there is no one. Do as I have ordered!

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Arthur!

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Arthur! Will you return?

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: All the knights of the Round Table are dead. Excalibur is returned. Arthur is gone. Maybe he lives, maybe he will return...

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Only I remain, and this...
